awd_titl_txt: Aspire-II - From Teacher Task Design to Generalizable Knowledge of Student Learning: A Comprehensive Study of Learning Progression Use
awd_abstract_narration:
The EHR Core Research program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. While learning progressions have shown promise as supports for teachers as they design formative assessments, as well as suggested new approaches for modeling student learning, the field is still only at the beginning stages of understanding how learning progressions can inform and enhance student learning. This research is needed because studies show that although formative assessment may support student learning, formative assessment practices are not easy for teachers to learn. Through this effort up to 72 high school biology, chemistry and physics teachers will participate in professional learning communities to help them become more effective in using learning progression-centered formative assessment in their classrooms. This project will build on prior studies by helping teachers in setting learning goals, measuring student progress toward those goals, and providing feedback to improve students' performance. It will also extend an ongoing research-practice partnership between a university-based educational research team and a school district that are both committed to improving science education for its population of socioeconomically, linguistically, and ethnically diverse students.

The overarching goals will be to investigate how teachers: (1) Engage with different types of learning progressions in different content domains to inform formative assessment design in professional learning communities; (2) Enact learning progression-based formative assessment tasks with students; (3) Measure the effect of learning progression-centered professional development on student learning, as well as the mediators of this effect; and will also (4) Model student learning and the extent to which assessment results support the hypotheses represented in learning progressions. The study will employ complementary qualitative and quantitative methods and follow a year of design-based implementation research with a quasi-experimental study of teachers participating in research-team facilitated professional learning communities focused on learning progressions. Evidence pertaining to teacher professional learning will be gathered through the triangulation of data from front-to-back analyses of teacher participation in professional learning communities, structured interviews, classroom observations, and analysis of formative assessment tasks. Student learning will be tracked through pre-post diagnostic assessments linked to learning progressions teachers use in their professional learning communities. Results from this work will advance knowledge about theory building through tools and resources along with evidence of their effectiveness, design criteria to guide formation of effective teacher collaboration around formative assessment design in professional learning communities, and model approaches for student performance relative to learning progressions. These end products will also provide instruments to help schools and districts collect evidence in real-time of professional learning community function and formative assessment task quality.

por.por_cntn:
The Aspire-II project developed and studied the influence of a learning progression for the crosscutting concept of energy. Crosscutting concepts link the domains of science and thus create opportunities for conversations about how to support and model student learning across multiple grade bands. Working in deep partnership with a school district, we examined how learning progressions supported teachers in long-term professional development focused on formative assessment co-design; studied teacher enactment of those assessments in their high school science classrooms; examined links with student learning; and established how different measurement models could capture student learning linked to the learning progression. 

Intellectual Merit

This project innovated an approach to longitudinal support of teaching and learning by tracing the crosscutting concept of energy through high school physics, chemistry, and biology courses. After piloting several different learning progressions with different design features, we developed a domain-general version of a learning progression that combined the crosscutting concept of energy with the science practice of modeling, and then developed domain-specific versions of the progression to support instructional units in each of the high school content areas. Our findings indicate that the progression supported teachers in coordinating their classroom practice around co-designed tasks, and in-depth coding of classroom videos indicates that while classroom enactment of the formative assessment tasks varied, teachers and students engaged in discussions at higher levels of the learning progression. 

We also innovated a new approach to summative assessment which we termed Phenomenon-Based Item Clusters (PBICs). These assessments created opportunities for students to read and respond to an accessible, everyday scenario with sets of structured multiple-choice questions that provided information about student understandings while also serving as scaffolding so that students would be prepared to engage with a two culminating prompts in which they are asked to create a model and use is to explain a transfer of energy depicted in the motivating scenario. We found that generating models and explanations in accord with the highest level of the learning progression to which each PBIC was targeted was challenging for many students. Use of an item response theory model with PBIC item responses helped to establish that empirical difficulty of PBIC items was in accord with intended difficulty. Diagnostic classifications of students according to learning progression levels was accomplished using two different psychometric modeling approaches (an item responses theory model, and a latent class model), each of which made different assumptions about the structure of the underlying construct.

Broader Impacts

Our learning progression ten served as the centerpiece for formative assessment co-design across multiple years in our partner school district. This project provided dozens of hours of school-based  professional development for teachers working in a culturally, linguistically, and socioeconomically diverse school district. Students had the opportunity to show what they know by engaging in phenomenon-based formative assessment, and to link their ideas and experiences with the science they were learning about in school. The project produced sets of instructional and professional learning resources that are in use beyond the scope of the original project, including facilitation guides for cycles of professional learning centered on learning progressions; tools and checklists to increase assessment accessibility for multilingual learners; as well as formative and summative assessments for modeling energy in high school physics, chemistry, and biology. In addition, the project supported the ongoing learning of 11 graduate students in science education, educational measurement, bilingual education, and the learning sciences.
